paper_title.en: Alloy Constitution Dependence of Strength and Deformation in Aluminum-Titanium-Vanadium Ternary Alloys Containing Gamma plus Beta Dual Phase Microstructures

description.en: Compression and compressive creep behavior was studied on Al-Ti-V ternary alloys containing gamma+beta dual phase microstructures, the gamma phase was based on an L(10) o face centered tetragonal lattice and the beta phase on a disordered body centered cubic lattice. Yield strength and its temperature dependence have been compared with those in the gamma and/or beta single phase materials. The ternary alloy compositions were located on one assumed conjugate line across the gamma+beta dula phase field, the terminal compositions for the gamma and beta phase constituents were Al(51)Ti(40)V(9) and Al(35)Ti(20)V(45), respectively (numbers in atomic %). Three other alloys were prepared that contained different fractions of the constituent gamma and beta phases The Al(47)Ti(35)V(18), Al(43)Ti(30)V(27), and Al(39)Ti(25)V(36) alloys contained beta phase by about 22, 57, and 76 % in their area fractions. All these alloys showed limited deformability at temperature below 900K. The 0.2% proof stresses of the alloys were described in a similar way as a combination law at the room temperature, the 0.2% proof stress increased from about 500 to 1000 MPa with increasing the vanadium content. The high strength of the alloys containing high level of vanadium retained up to 900K, but the proof stress drastically diminished as the temperature was raised above 900K Under compressive creep tests performed at temperatures ranging from 1100 to 1200 K, the minimum creep rates were smaller in the alloys containing less vanadium, and this could be ascribed to the fact that the beta phase was much softer than the gamma phase at higher temperatures than about 1000K

paper_title.en: Mechanical properties of Ll(2) modified titanium trialuminides alloyed with chromium, iron and vanadium

description.en: L1(2) modified titanium trialuminides have been prepared by replacing 9 mol% of aluminum in Al3Ti with ternary and quaternary alloying elements of chromium, iron and vanadium. All the materials were recrystallized into single-phase polycrystals with average grain diameters of about 40 mum. Lattice parameters of the 9 at.% chromium- and 9 at.% iron-modified materials were 0.3959 and 0.3939 nm, respectively. Lattice parameters linearly increased with vanadium addition as the fourth element. Compression tests were performed at temperatures ranging from an ambient temperature up to 1300 K. Yield strength was not sensitive to chemical composition among chromium- and iron-modified materials, but it increased with vanadium addition. Strengthening effect of vanadium was retained up to high temperatures. Compressive creep rates at around 1200 K showed the same effect of vanadium. Flow stress fluctuation of about a few percent was observed in an intermediate temperature range. At 500 K, the flow stress began to fluctuate after several percents of plastic deformation, and it continued through the test. At around 600 K, serrations started immediately after yielding and continued to the end. At 800 K, flow stress fluctuations occurred just after yielding. (C) 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING A-STRUCTURAL MATERIALS PROPERTIES MICROSTRUCTURE AND PROCESSING

paper_title.en: Deformation parameters governing tensile elongation for a mechanically milled Al-1.1at.%Mg-1.2at.%Cu alloy tested in tension at constant true strain rates

description.en: For a mechanically milled Al-1.1at.%Mg-1.2at.%Cu alloy, tensile deformation was carried out at temperatures of 523-823 K and at true strain rates of 1 × 10-3 - 5 × 100/s. The analysis of true stress-true strain curves from a dislocation dynamics viewpoint showed that a large value of re-mobilization probability of unlocked immobile dislocations Ω is mainly responsible for an enormous elongation (1.3 in true strain) observed at an intermediate strain rate (100/s) and temperature (748 K). Discussion on thermally activated process for Ω and dislocation kinetics indicated that the suppression of plastic instability leading to superplastic elongation is controlled by liberating immobile dislocations from a solute atmosphere. The strain rate sensitivity m was formulated on a basis of dislocation dynamics, and a relation of Ω ∝ m2 was found to hold between them.

publication_name.en: Acta Materialia

paper_title.en: Chemical composition effects on the creep strength of gamma-base titanium aluminides alloyed with vanadium
paper_title.ja: Chemical Composition Effects onthe Creep Strength ofγ-base TitaniumAluminides Alloyedwith Vanadium

description.en: The present study investigates the alloying effects of vanadium on the creep of polycrystalline materials of gamma-base titanium aluminides containing 50 or 55 at.% aluminum. The vanadium content was varied from 0 to 25 at.% at 5 at.% intervals. The materials containing less vanadium showed single phase gamma structure, but materials with a higher vanadium content contained a small volume fraction of beta phase. The creep behavior at 1200K was investigated by compressive creep tests conducted in vacuum. The compressive creep behavior of the alloys at 1200K revealed that the minimum creep rate decreased with increasing vanadium content in the single phase materials, but increased in materials containing beta phase. The creep rate exhibited a minimum at 5 at.% and 10-15 at.% vanadium, in materials containing 50 at.% and 55at.% aluminum, respectively. The vanadium addition enhanced the creep strength of single phase gamma-TiAl, but the presence of the beta phase was found to be harmful to the creep strength of gamma-base titanium aluminides.

publication_name.en: GAMMA TITANIUM ALUMINIDES 1999
publication_name.ja: TMS“Gamma TitaniumAluminides 1999”733-740

paper_title.en: Origin of superplastic elongation in aluminum alloys produced by mechanical milling

description.en:
The effects of alloying (Mg, Cu, Ge and/or Si) and prior rolling and annealing on tensile stress-strain behaviors were examined for mechanically milled, powder metallurgy aluminum alloys at 748 K in the strain rate range of 1 × 10-4-7.5 × 102/s. Lowering the temperature of prior rolling and increasing the anneal temperature and time result in an increase in the strain rate sensitivity, m. Especially alloying effectively increases the m value as well as the strain to fracture, εf, at the intermediate strain rate of approximately 100/s
 m and εf reach 0.4 and 440% for a case of alloying both 1.1 at.% Mg and 1.2at.% Cu, though they are smaller than 0.1 and 100% at lower (&lt
 1 × 10-2/s) and higher (&gt
 5 &gt
 101/s) strain rates. TEM and SEM revealed that the microstructure of superplastic alloys, compared to pure Al, consists of thermally recovered, fine equiaxed grains (smaller than 1 μm in diameter) with smooth grain boundaries of large misorientation. It is then postulated that superplastic elongation occurs when smooth boundaries slide under a plastically stable condition due to a large m value. © 1998 Acta Metallurgica Inc. Published by Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: Acta Materialia

paper_title.en: Alloying effect of vanadium on the structure and strength of gamma-phase titanium aluminides with aluminum-rich compositions
paper_title.ja: Alloying Effect of Vanadium on theStructure and Strengthof γ-phase TitaniumAluminides withAluminum-RichCompositions

description.en: The effect of vanadium upon the structure and strength of gamma-phase titanium aluminide polycrystals containing 55 at.% aluminum has been investigated. The vanadium content was varied from 0 to 20 at.% at 5 at.% intervals. Equiaxed polycrystals were prepared by recrystallizing the hot-deformed materials. The materials containing up to 15 at.% vanadium showed a single phase gamma-structure, but the 20 at.% vanadium material contained a small volume fraction of beta-phase solid solution based on vanadium. The lattice parameters, a and c, both decreased but the axial ratio, c/a, increased with increasing vanadium content, suggesting that vanadium enhanced the tetragonality of the substitutional solid solution. The 0.2% proof stress increases with increasing vanadium content between room temperature and 1300 K, and appears to be a solid solution strengthening effect. (C) 1997 Elsevier Science S.A.

publication_name.en: MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING A-STRUCTURAL MATERIALS PROPERTIES MICROSTRUCTURE AND PROCESSING

paper_title.en: Alloying effect of vanadium upon structure and strength of delta-phase titanium trialuminide
paper_title.ja: Alloying Effect ofVanadium uponStructure and Strengthof δ-phase TitaniumTrialuminide

description.en: The alloying effect of vanadium upon delta-phase titanium trialuminide has been investigated using materials whose compositions were of the type Al-3(Ti,V). Six types of ternary aluminum-titanium-vanadium alloys, ranging from A13Ti to Al3V at 5 atomic % intervals, have been prepared by are melting. All the materials showed the D0(22) tetragonal structure, suggesting vanadium atoms substitute titanium atoms. The 0.2% proof stress increased with increasing vanadium content up to about 10 atomic %, and then decreased toward that of Al3V both at room temperature and at elevated temperatures. Such behavior can be interpreted as substitutional solid solution strengthening.

publication_name.en: HIGH-TEMPERATURE ORDERED INTERMETALLIC ALLOYS VII
publication_name.ja: Mat. Res. Soc.Symp. Proc.460, 91-96“High-TemperatureOrdered IntermetallicAlloys Ⅶ”

paper_title.en: Effects of addition of alloying elements on superplastic behavior in mechanically alloyed aluminum alloys

description.en: Effects of addition of Mg, Cu, Ge and Si on stress vs strain behavior in tension were examined at 748K under strain rates of 10(-4)-10(3)/s and analyzed from a viewpoint of microstructure in P/M Al alloys produced by mechanical alloying. The content of alloying element was within the solubility limit at 748K. The alloys showed the maximum of elongation to failure in a middle range of strain rate (similar to 10(-1)-similar to 10/s). Further, its peak value increased with increasing alloying content, and exceeded 400% in the case of the combined addition of 1.1at%Mg and 1.2at%Cu. With alloying, on the other hand, the logarithm of flow stress decreased notably at low strain rates (below similar to 10(-2)/s) but remained almost constant at high strain rates (above similar to 10(2)/s), producing a large m value in the middle range of strain rate. TEM prior to deformation showed that the alloys consisted of grains smaller than 1 mu m in size. Further, it was found that microstructure had become more well-defined by the alloying, resulting in fewer dislocations within grains and more smooth grain boundaries with a larger misorientation. Such sharpening of microstructure was verified also by an X-ray diffraction method. During deformation grains elongated in the tensile direction, but their aspect ratio never exceeded about two even after straining of more than 400%. Further, when elongation was large, grain boundary sliding occurred in most of boundaries from the beginning of deformation, along with less cavitation. It was concluded that the alloying made microstructure well-defined and boundaries smooth and superplastic deformation occurred mainly by the sliding of such smooth boundaries under the stable plastic condition due to a large m value.

publication_name.en: TOWARDS INNOVATION IN SUPERPLASTICITY I

Deformation parameters governing tensile elongation for a mechanically milled Al-1.1at.%Mg-1.2at.%Cu alloy tested in tension at constant true strain rates

description.en: For a mechanically milled Al-1.1at.%Mg-1.2at.%Cu alloy. tensile deformation was carried out at temperatures of 523-823 K and at true strain rates of 1 x 10(-3)-5 x 10(0)/s. The analysis of true stress-true strain curves from a dislocation dynamics viewpoint showed that a large value of re-mobilization probability of unlocked immobile dislocations Omega is mainly responsible for an enormous elongation (1.3 in true strain) observed at an intermediate strain rate (100/s) and temperature (748 K). Discussion on thermally activated process for Omega and dislocation kinetics indicated that the suppression of plastic instability leading to superplastic elongation is controlled by liberating immobile dislocations from a solute atmosphere. The strain rate sensitivity m was formulated on a basis of dislocation dynamics, and a relation of Omega proportional to m(2) was found to field between them. (C) 2000 Acta Metallurgica Inc. Published by Elsevier Science Ltd. AN rights reserved.
